gov.fnal.ppd.dd.chat

Class MessageCarrier

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.fnal.ppd.dd.chat.MessageCarrier
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class MessageCarrier
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    This class holds the messages that will be exchanged between the Clients and the Server. When talking from a Java Client to a Java Server, it is a lot easier to stream Java objects, so that is what we do here. TODO -- replace this class and the XML classes with one, unified message, probably in JSON. It would be best, at that time, to stop streaming a Java object here so that other languages can get into the game--we would just stream ASCII messages. Off the top of my head, here is what a JSON message that carries all the information might looks like. 
     { "message": {
     "Type"    : "message",
     "To"      : "destinationClientName",
     "From"    : "sourceClientName",
     "IP"      : "131.225.1.1",
     "Date"    : "Jan 1, 2015 12:34:56 CST",
     "Display" : "12",
     "Screen"  : "0",
     "Content" : {
            "Type" : "Web Page",
          "Name" : "Channel Name",
          "URI"  : "http://www.fnal.gov",
          "Time" : "0",
          "Code" : "0",         
     }
     "Signature" : "82736152635fe62de82ab7fe901ab82",
   }
 }
    As stated above, if/when we change to this JSON scheme, it will be important NOT to stream an object.
    Author:
    Elliott McCrory, Fermilab AD/Instrumentation
    See Also:

        to - The recipient of the message
        message - The message itself. It is anticipated that this will be just a statement of the error (i.e., not XML)
